Transcript: [Written on The Dodge Hotel note card]  [October 2, 1934 pm] Tuesday Nite 8 o’clock  Bird,  Watchfully waited all day but no letter. My last word was Thursday nite.  I know, you too,--haven’t received letters some days and I hope they didn’t make you feel as I do. Be a good little girl and think of   Lyndon  [Envelope postmarked: Washington, D.C., 10/2/1934, 9:30 PM; “Missent to______”; also postmarked: Winnsboro, Tex, 10/8/1934, 8 AM] [No stamp on envelope]  [Transcript prepared by LBJ Library staff, January 2013]
Title: Note, Lyndon Johnson to Lady Bird Taylor, October 2, 1934.
Creator: Lyndon Baines Johnson
Abstract: LBJ says he has not received a letter from Lady Bird since Thursday night; he asks her to "Be a good little girl and think of Lyndon."
Collection: The Personal Papers of Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson are a collection of correspondence between Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson that spans 1934 through 1968. During the Johnsons’ years in the White House, Dorothy Territo, a staff assistant who maintained files of high historical value, as well as family and genealogical material, had custody of the collection. In 1969, the files she kept came to Austin as part of President Johnson’s papers, which he had deeded to the U.S. government in August 1965.This collection includes the courtship letters between Lyndon Johnson and Claudia "Lady Bird" Taylor, from the period between their introduction and their marriage, September – November 1934.
Citation: “Note, Lyndon Johnson to Lady Bird Taylor, October 2, 1934. ,” Personal Papers of Lyndon B. and Lady Bird Johnson, LBJ Presidential Library, Dear Bird: The 1934 Courtship Letters, accessed November 27, 2016, http://archives.lbjlibrary.org/items/show/399.
